Comments_List: The importance of the integration between laboratory and clinical research for the understanding of disease and the development of new, life-saving treatments. We learned how to write a grant which is a valuable skill.

I learned an immense amount of very applied information about a selection of important autoimmune disorders, including their associated phenotypes, animal models, molecular mechanisms, and current standard of care. I learned to view problems in the field of immunobiology for a translational perspective, in which the ultimate goal is to improve patient outcomes.

Literature review
Project proposal
Translational perspective in medicine
Immunology
I learned The importance of immunologists in several systems and the skill of applying mechanisms to design solutions to pathologies

I learned about several human diseases and the way that the immune system contributes to their development. I also learned about how the immune system can be altered to try and treat these diseases. 

Throughout the course we also learned a bit about how to write a grant.

Really good speakers; however, it was difficult to determine which information would be important from the lecture in order to answer the homework questions. The powerpoints were also not always available, making the homework difficult. Perhaps a broader-based, pre-lecture assignment that helps to channel the focus of students, especially because there are students from a variety of backgrounds in the class, would be beneficial for understanding, as well as to facilitate more meaningful discussion with the guest lecturer. Alternatively, if the class met two times per week - once earlier in the week for an overview of the presentation topic and its important, associated immunological principles by Dr. O'Connor (or this could be optional for students who  do not have a strong immunology background, or students simply interested in knowing more) this could be extremely helpful as well.

Strengths:
- Lectures from leaders in each disease provided a highly relevant and up-to-date perspective on what is known in the field. 
- Small class size provided space for student engagement.
- Only having one lecture per week allowed me to tag this on as a sixth class.

Drawbacks:
- At times, having a different lecturer every period led to a lack of cohesiveness throughout the course; this format lacked central themes, to an extent, though these were emphasized throughout the homework, which served as a source of consistency.

Strengths:
1. Very interactive class
2. Timely feedback on assignments
3. Humor instructors
4. Latest & most advanced look into translational medicine

Weakness:
1. Could add sessions that discuss about problem sets
2. Could do a wrap-up that summarizes different diseases and most advanced/effective treatment

The course was very diverse in its reach which was good. I wish The lectures were recorded and that we were assured the slides and notes. I also Wish the homework were more closely related to the lectures.

The strength was the class project of writing a translational immunology grant. It was a great way to learn in depth about a specific area of translational immunology and was a good way to learn general grant writing skills. 

I wish the course went more in depth into the immunology.
I would definitely recommend to any student interested in learning more about immunology beyond the basics; especially to anyone who desires to work in the realm of clinical practice or research.
Yes, anyone who's interested in medicine and immunology should take this class. This is very helpful to make you think in the immunology perspective.
If you have a strong understanding of basic immunologic concepts -- yes.
